Two forms: [NCN] and [NC–N] are adopted in [NCN] groups. Crystal structures for cyanamides, oxides and sulfides (bottom). The same coordination mode introduces the similarity in structure for them. Fig. 2 The periodic table of elements for cyanamides. The elements in yellow are corresponding to existed binary cyanamides while the blue means the cyanamides with multiple ions. Fig. 3 Typical coordination forms for metal cyanamides in different blocks. (a) Octahedral coordination for metals withdivalent cations (Mg2+, Ca2+ and Mn2+) in s- and d-block. (b) Different four coordination modes for ZnNCN (tetrahedron) and CuNCN (plane), two coordination mode for HgNCN (line) in ds-block. (c) Seven coordination modes for metals in f-block (Sm3+, Pr3+, Nd3+, Eu3+, Dy3+, Ho3+, Tm3+, Yb3+and Er3+). (d) Four coordination mode for SnNCN and five coordination mode for PbNCN in p-block. Fig. 4 Typical crystal lattice for metal cyanamides possess holey structures. (a) Typical cyanamides withdivalent cations (Mg2+, Ca2+, Mn2+and Cd2+), octahedral coordination and R −3mH space group in s- or d-block. (b) Four coordination modes for ZnNCN (space group: I −42d) and CuNCN (space group: C mcm) in ds-block. (c) Typical cyanamides withtrivalent cations (Sm3+, Pr3+, Nd3+, Eu3+, Dy3+, Ho3+, Tm3+, Yb3+and Er3+), polyhedral coordination and P −3m1 space group in f-block. (d) Polyhedral coordination for SnNCN (four coordination mode) with I 12/a1 space group and PbNCN (five coordination mode) with P na21 space group in p-block. Fig. 5 Typical properties for metal cyanamides. (a) Molar magnetic susceptibility for MnNCN together with trend lines. Reproduced from Ref. [102] with permission from American Physical Society. (b) Inverse molar magnetic susceptibility versus temperature plot for Cr2(NCN)3. Insert: magnetic hysteretic loop with fields up to 5 T at a temperature of 10 K. Reproduced from Ref. Graphical abstract Cyanamides taking organic quasi-linear [NCN]2− as the anion, possess spacious and conjugated structure, which exhibit striking performance in catalysis, battery and luminescence. Metal cyanamides are an emerging class of functional materials with potential applications in sustainable energy conversion and storage technologies such as catalysis, supercapacitors, photoluminescence and next-gen batteries. The [NCN]2− as the anion, which is isolobal with [O]2− endows metal cyanamides with similar physicochemical properties as oxides and chalcogenides. Whereas the unique quasi-linear structure and electronic resonance between [NCN]2− and [N–CN]2− of [NCN] entity bring out superior properties beyond oxides and chalcogenides. In this review, we present research status, challenges, and the recent striking progress on the metal cyanamides in the synthesis and applications. Specifically, the characteristic structures, physicochemical properties, synthetic methods with corresponding merits/demerits and latest applications in energy conversion and storage of cyanamides are summarized. The detailed outlooks for the new compounds design, morphology manipulation and potential applications are also exhibited. Keywords Metal cyanamides Structure Properties Synthesis Energy applications 1 Introduction Metal oxides and chalcogenides are extensively studied by scholars because of their advance in facile synthesis, inexpensive source and abundant properties in physics and chemistry, which results in their broad applications in catalysis [1–5], sensors [6–8], labels [9,10], drug loading [11,12], energy conversation [13–17], storage [18–22] etc. However, there are still many intrinsic deficiencies for conventional materials challenging future applications. Most metal oxides suffer from low light harvest and low conductivity owing to wide band gap more than 3 eV, such as TiO2 [23,24], SnO2 [25], Nb2O5 [26,27] and ZnO [28,29]. Then, instability currently happens in most chalcogenides, as the photocorrosion [30–32] under the light and the solubility of polysulfide [33–35] during the long-time charge/discharge cycles. Many works devoted to overcome these problems, such as morphological engineering [36–39], hetero-atom doping [40,41], heterojunctions construction [42–44], surface coating [45,46] and some mixed methods [47,48] of aforementioned these. Nevertheless, many deficiencies still remain unsolved, like high redox potentials as anodes and low stability in long cycle in energy storage. Thus, looking for new kinds of functional materials grows up as an urgent work for scholars. Cyanamides with a general formula Mχ(NCN)γ (M = alkali, alkaline-earth, rare-earth, transition metal or metalloid), taking [NCN]2− as the anion, is a family of multi-atom ion composed compounds. It arises from the organic synthesis of cyanogen [49,50] and is well known from CaNCN [51,52] in steel and fertilizer industry in 1960s. [NCN] group as an analogy with O, not only has similar electronegativity values (3.36) with O (3.47), but also has the same charge (-2) [53]. The similarity in coordination number between cyanamides, oxides and chalcogenides, such as hexa-coordinate for Cr3+, Fe2+, Co2+ and Ni2+ [54–56] (Fig. 1 ) making their homologous characters in physics and chemistry. Apart from these, the added structural complexity to the crystal always endows these compounds with novel and/or enhanced properties like high photovoltaic characteristics [57], tunable bandgap [58] and various structures [59]. Typically, [NCN]2− anions adopt two electronic forms: [NCN]2− and [NC–N]2− in compounds (Fig. 1), which illustrates π electrons flowing among bonds, helping improve carriers’ mobility rate. It not only elevates charges’ separation efficiency in photocatalysis and enhances activity [60,61], but also improves electrons conductivity and makes sense in electrochemical applications. The compounds with [N=C=N]2− are typically called as carbodiimides while the cyanamides are considered possessing [N≡C–N]2−. In order to simplify the namespace, cyanamides are chosen as the representative of this kind of compounds here. Then, the spacious crystal structure resulted from parallel aligned [NCN]2− brings about abundant channel and enhances endurance of the compounds, which achieves structures design with remarkable cycle performance in batteries [55,62]. The preparation of metal cyanamides in a pure and well-defined state has not been unambiguously achieved before 1994. More than 80 kinds of metal cyanamides were synthesized and shown in the periodic table of elements (Fig. 2 ). Dronskowski et al [63] have made a forecast about the reasonable future of cyanamides as energy materials. Their already exhibited interesting properties as the negative electrode reveal the exciting future. Among them, MnNCN [62] and FeNCN [55] have been applied as electrode materials with striking performance while Ag2NCN [61] has exhibited good photocatalytic activity under visible light. Then, electrocatalysis [64–66], photovoltaic devices [57], fluorescent light sources [67,68], and light-emitting diodes [69,70] are also reported for cyanamides contributed from their structure, showing multifunctional features. However, there are still many compounds leaving untouched in this family owing to few people dabbling in them. The synthetic strategies are limited, resulting in challenges in new compounds fabrication, morphological manipulation and applications research. Therefore, we review the recent progress in metal cyanamides structures, morphological regulation methods and applications in battery, supercapacitor and catalysis. Apart from these, some perspectives about synthesis and potential applications are offered for future development. Relationships between structures, physicochemical properties, and application performance of metal cyanamides are also discussed. 2 Structure and physicochemical properties 2.1 Structures Quasi-linear anion [NCN]2− in metal cyanamides bring up loose and holey crystal structures shown in Fig. 4 and Table 1 . The existed cyanamide compounds are mostly fabricated by solid-state metathesis (SSM) using Li2NCN as the precursor. The most famous one for its extensive applications in fertilizer and steel industry is CaNCN from the reaction of Li2NCN and CaCl2 [51,52], so as rare earth compound Ln2(NCN)3 [71,72] and SnNCN [73]. Another similar reaction chooses cations Cr3+, Mn2+, Zr4+and Hf4+ [56,74,75] to exchange with Zn2+ in ZnNCN to get cyanamides. The different coordination modes of typical cyanamides are shown in Fig. 3 . Among them, octahedral coordination with trigonal system is the most popular one for divalent cations in s- and d-block, where MnNCN is the typical cyanamide with distorted rock salt structure (Fig. 3a and 4a). The cations Mn2+ are cubic close-packed with six [NCN]2− coordination. The parallel [NCN]2− anions create one-dimension channel with a diameter more than 3.0 Å. Then, the four coordination modes are universal in ds-block as ZnNCN and CuNCN. The tetrahedral coordination for ZnNCN brings about channels as large as 3.15 Å and the planar coordination for CuNCN leads to a layer spacing more than 3 Å (Fig. 3b and 4b). By the way, there is a two-coordination mode for HgNCN in this block that exhibiting a linear structure (Fig. 3b). Then, the lone pair electrons in Sn2+ and Pb2+ endow their cyanamides with typical four or five coordination mode to form complex polyhedron in p-block. The channels have a size of 2.50 Å in SnNCN and 2.68 Å in PbNCN (Fig. 3d and 4d), which is a bit smaller than the aforementioned cyanamides. Owing to spacious crystal structure arising from [NCN]2−, it is common to accompany other ions in frameworks achieving the complicated polyionic cyanamides. The ternary cyanamides fabricated through SSM reactions can be divided into two parts: polycationic and polyanionic compounds. Some metal chlorides react withexcess Li2NCN to realize ternary cyanamides as LiM(NCN)2 with Li+ occupying in M3+ position, such as Al3+, Yb3+, In3+ and Ln3+ [68,76]. Then, similar reactions are also performed for Sn4+, Zr4+, Hf4+ [77] with Li2NCN or Na2NCN resulting another general formula for ternary cyanamides as A2M(NCN)3 (A = Li+, Na+). Of course, cations with divalent value in a stable lattice like ZnNCN also have the capacity to tolerate another divalent cations to form polycationic compounds as SrZn(NCN)2 [78] and BaZn(NCN)2 [79] . Polyanionic cyanamides adding M−O bonds in the lattice result from metal oxides or derivatives to react with A2NCN (A = Li+, Na+). (MO)χ+ as one kind of cation exchange with A+ to get new compounds like (BiO)2NCN, Sn2ONCN and (LnO)2NCN [58,80,81]. The coordination mode and structure of (LnO)2NCN in f-block are shown in Fig. 3c and 4c. The Ln3+ cations adopt seven coordination, which includes four O and three [NCN] groups. The channels separated by [NCN] between the layer of Ln3+ are about 3.3 Å. The higher coordination numbers than MnNCN and ZnNCN enlarge the size of the holes. Apart from these, many multi-anion cyanamides are coming from SSM reactions as the intermediates, such as Sn4Cl2(NCN)3, Hg2Cl2NCN, Sr2Cl2NCN and LaCl(NCN)2 [73,82–84]. The quaternary cyanamides [85,86] are usually from the intermediates to obtain polyionic compounds combining multiple cations and anions. 2.2 Physicochemical properties The unique anion [NCN]2− not only builds cyanamides with spacious structures, but also endows abundant characteristic properties in physics and chemistry. The similarities in electronegativity, charged value [53] and coordination modes for [NCN] and O lead to analogous properties in magnetism for cyanamides and oxides [56,102]. However, the electronegativity of [NCN] locates between O and S, indicating the medium splitting of energy levels for cyanamides compared with oxides and chalcogenides. Thus, the band gaps of cyanamides are normally smaller than oxides while larger than chalcogenides (Table 2 ) [57,61,103]. The smaller energy gap, open framework and conjugated anions create higher electron and ion mobility for cyanamides [61,62,104]. Of course, there are still a few cyanamides having a larger band gap than that of corresponding oxides or a smaller gap than that of corresponding sulfides (Table 2). On the other hand, the organic anions also result in the thermal instability [56,105–107] of cyanamides. The detailed physicochemical properties are discussed as the following: (1) Magnetism. The magnetic properties of the cyanamides are similar to those of the isolobal oxides, especially in divalent transition metals like Mn2+ [102]. MnNCN exhibits antiferromagnetic interactions as a function of temperature (Fig. 5 a). However, there is the transition metal cyanamide Cr2(NCN)3 [56] (Fig. 5b) that indeed shows ferromagnetic properties not like its crystallographically related oxide - Cr2O3. The more covalent Cr-N bond and related lower ligand-field splitting may count in its magnetism property. (2) Band structures. The most existed metal cyanamides are reported as semiconductors and the known band gaps are shown in Table 2. FeNCN [108], CoNCN and NiNCN [54] are considered as metallic or half-metallic compounds while semi-conductivity of FeNCN [109] have been reported in photocatalysis owing to the severe underestimation of electronic correlations in the calculation. The CuNCN and Ag2NCN are typically compounds possessing striking photo-electron response and their band structures are shown in Fig. 5c and 5d [57,61,103]. The strong hybridization between M−NCN−M causes dispersion of the CBM/VBM and favors high electron mobility [61]. (3) Stability. Nearly all of the cyanamides can exist in the neutral and alkaline solvent while exhibit much more instability than corresponding oxides and chalcogenides (except Cr2(NCN)3 [56]) in acidic environment even in organic acid like hexanoic acid. It is owing to the higher stability of H2NCN under high concentration of H+ [56,105]. Apart from these, we found some compounds like PbNCN and SnNCN dissolving in some polyols like triethanolamine. The high affinity between Pb2+/Sn2+ and oxygen breaks down the bindings in cyanamides. The thermal stability of the cyanamides is also poor thanks to organic anions [NCN]2−. The typical thermogravimetric decomposition curve coupled with mass spectrometry analysis are shown in Fig. 5e and 5 f. N2, NH3 and C2N2 are the typical products of cyanamides under high temperature. On the other hand, the instability can make sense in structure design like hollow nanoparticles [105] or carbon materials with controllable nitrogen content [106,107]. However, the lack of family members in cyanamides leads to the short in the diversity of properties, such as superconductivity. Hence, more strategies should be taken to achieve the synthesis and manipulation of new compounds or new structures. 3 Synthesis and morphological regulation Most of the existed metal cyanamides are synthesized through SSM reactions. In a typical process, the reaction is as follows: χ L i 2 NCN + 2 MC l χ = M 2 NCN χ + 2 χ LiCl SSM reactions involve an exchange of ions [128], corresponding to Mχ+ and Li+ here. As is reported by Pearson [129], Li+ is one of the hardest acids in the table. [NCN]2− with delocalized electrons and larger size [129] than Cl− is difinitely soft. LiCl is more stable than Li2NCN based on HSAB theory, leading to the products of new metal cyanamides. It is a facile and effective strategy to obtain new compounds and realize doping for cyanamides in a furnace. The biggest shortcoming for this method is the resulted size which is too large to apply efficiently in applications like energy storage and catalysis. Nevertheless, the synthetic manipulation of cyanamides still remians infancy owing to complicated anions [NCN]2− and few choices in their reactants. Itisurgentto seek controllable methods for the next generation of synthesis. In order to promote the chemical synthesis of cyanamides and boost their further development, the strategies to obtain metal cyanamides, their relative merits and demerits are summarized in the following. 3.1 Solvothermal-assisted calcination [NCN]2− anions offered by alkali and alkaline-earth metal cyanamides during the SSM reactions comes from the breaking of ionic bonds, which needs abundant energy provided by the high temperature. Thus, if there are proper materials to donor [NCN]2− at relatively lower temperature, it would be more convenient to realize morphological manipulation. Cyanamide (H2CN2) with the high activity can work as an ideal donor to react with metal precursor while dicyandiamide polymerized from H2CN2 above 122 °C and urea got from H2CN2 hydrolysis [130] also come into effect as candidates (Fig. 6 c) [131,132]. However, there are few reports claiming a successful synthesis using cyanamide, dicyandiamide or urea through calcination. As a matter of fact, all of them turn into melamine at 350 °C [131] to work and the relatively lower temperature cannot break the bonds of N–H. Thus, melamine becomes the most common choice to offer [NCN]2− for metal cyanamides synthesis. As is reported, MgNCN [90] can be obtained through calcination from Mg3N2 and melamine, as well as SrNCN and BaNCN while Ln2O3 reacts with melamine help derive (LnO)2NCN [133]. After annealing, microcrystalline products are produced for analysis without impurities. In order to figure out the [NCN] originated mechanism, the thermal polymerization process of melamine is explored and offers an idea. According to Antonietti et al [131], the products of polymerization are clearly exhibited through differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) and Density functional theory (DFT). During the heating up to about 390 °C, the units of C3N4 formvia melamine rearrangements. Then, condensation of these units topolymers, networks and potentially the final polymeric C3N4 occurs at around 520 °C.These units play a key role in the condensation to get g-C3N4 as well as the pyrolysis to obtain metal cyanamides. As shown in Fig. 6a and 6b, two structures can be got after further annealing with melamine than 390 °C. DFT calculations indicate that the tri-s-triazine based structure seems to be more stable than triazine [134]. Thus, the unit of g-C3N4 is based on tri-s-triazine rather than triazine while the pyrolysis of melamine may choose triazine as the intermediate to boost the break of C–N bonds to form [NCN]2−. The excess C in triazine can react with oxides to form CO2 flowing away or with nitrides to get another [NCN]2−. In order to realize morphology manipulation of metal cyanamides, some strategies are applied based on melamine, shown in Fig. 7 . As Cao et al reported [62], octanoic acid is chosen as the connect bridge to combine melamine and MnCl2. After hydrothermally treated at 180 °C, the products are calcined at 500 °C to get MnNCN. The achieved precursors and compounds all exhibit a 2D morphology (Fig. 7a-c) with remarkable performances in energy storage. Apart from this, further manipulation of FeNCN nanorods (Fig. 7d-f) through melamine is also reported by Wang et al [109]. It is the first time that a regular shape of metal cyanamides is synthesized by calcination. They used molten salt to offer a liquid environment to realize the selective growth and get nanorods (Fig. 7e) while only nanoparticles (Fig. 7f) can be obtained without assist of molten salt. Of course, the inert atmosphere is quite significant to keep the precursor away from the oxygen, which will oxidize the cyanamides into corresponding oxides. After substituting precursors with melamine, the mild conditions make it possible to access morphology manipulation compared with SSM reactions. According to the polycondensation process of melamine, the synthesis can be theoretically achieved at a relatively lower temperature than 400 °C. Before annealing process, the precursors exhibit sheet-like or rod-like morphology. The resulted metal cyanamides keep their shapes of the precursors and show their appealing performances in energy storage and environment purification. Nevertheless, the manipulation in morphology still remains in the preliminary without further expansion in size and different shapes. The reaction conditions are a little harsh and out of control to some extent during the synthesis process, which are the common problems with calcination. Hence, the methods applied in the solution maybe the real solutions to overcome these problems. 3.2 Solution-based synthesis Solid state reactions are superior in operations and structure manipulation but fail in morphological control and performance applications. Soft chemical synthesis in the solution conquers critical conditions for solid state reactions and realizes a breakthrough in academic research and applications. Coprecipitation, sol–gel, solvothermal, one-pot, micro-emulsion, self-assemble strategies and many other soft methods [135,136] reported to work for controllable synthesis, showing few equipmentrequirements and good control in chemistry, are certainly becoming the fabrication trend of new materials. Thus, more work should be done to promote the synthesis of metal cyanamides with soft chemical methods. Till now, there are many cases for metal cyanamides fabricated in the solution taking H2CN2 as the precursor, which can be divided into two groups-direct and indirect method. The classification is based on the final products from the solution. The metal cyanamides obtained as Mχ(NCN)γ in the solution are defined as direct synthesis while only intermediates can be derived and should be processed with other crafts, called as indirect synthesis. The detailed strategies and mechanism are illustrated below. 3.2.1 Direct coprecipitation Firstly, some metal cations can react with H2CN2 to get metal cyanamides directly in the solution, such as Ag+, Cu2+, Mn2+, Zn2+, Cd2+, Hg2+, Tl+ and Pb2+ [57,59,61,91,98,100,101,137]. Among them, Ag+ is the most active cation that substitute H+ in the H2CN2 immediately to form Ag2NCN once they are mixed. In order to restrict its growth, some extra substrate like g-C3N4 nanosheets were used by Huang et al [60] to realize the dispersed growth of Ag2NCN through anchoring effect from excessive N atoms on the plane. The resulted Ag2NCN nanoparticles are ca. 20 nm showing in Fig. 8 j and 8k. However, the others have to adopt bases to seize the H+ and release [NCN]2−, where ammonia as an inorganic agent is widely used. In some cases [59,101], NaOH is chosen to provide alkalinity in water but few can realize a successful synthesis without byproducts. The insolubility of many hydroxides takes this responsibility in OH– competing with [NCN]2− for metal cations, such as Cd2+, Mn2+ and Cu2+ . Then, ammonia not only has the capability to combine H+ and release [NCN]2−, but also is good at coordination with cations to get rid of precipitation resulted by high pH values. As Huang and Fang reported [57,61], the concentration of ammonia plays a prominent role in the morphology manipulation of cyanamides, which are shown in Fig. 8. A higher [NH3]/[Mχ+] ratio results in a larger crystal size, by contrast, a small agglomeration composed by nanoparticles is obtained from the relatively low ratio (Fig. 8a-f). The mechanism is believed to be the “protection” of ammonia coordinated in the cations that brings about less nucleation at first and large products at last. Although the control in crystal size and shape remains in microparticles, the synthesis reactions happen in the solution unveil the door of manipulation for metal cyanamides. As a matter of fact, the key to realize the synthesis of metal cyanamides through soft chemical strategies is taking H+ from H2CN2. Ammonia and sodium hydroxide are the examples to achieve this. Thus, a conclusion can be drawn that two points are needed: (1) Bases react with H2CN2 to release [NCN]2−; (2) Protect metal cations from precipitation before complex with [NCN]2−. Then, as conventional crystal growth theory [138,139] and sol–gel nucleation and growth theory [140,141] illustrate, a fast nucleation process accompanied by moderate slow growth results in a series of uniform nanoparticles, among which the former always dominates in the control of size down to nanoscale. Thus, proper bases will achieve a controllable size for metal cyanamides. The particularly significant point is (3) Appropriate bases worked as catalysts boosting the nucleation to realize morphology manipulation. Inorganic soluble bases based on OH– anions to work suffer from few choices and high risk of hydroxides precipitations, which are not suitable for the controllable synthesis of metal cyanamides. However, organic bases with a higher “hardness” than [NCN]2− could get over all these shortcomings to obtain cyanamides. There are many kinds of effective organic amines (R-NHχ, χ = 0, 1, 2) working as Lewis bases and keeping away from byproducts like hydroxides. Apart from this, the organic group “R-” with abundant choices determines the magnitude of basicity even turn out as surfactants for morphological manipulation. There have been some amines reported for fabrication like oleylamine, hexadecylamine, octadecanamine [98] and benzylamine [105,118,137]. As shown in Fig. 9 a-f, it is claimed by Huang et al [98], oleylamine, hexadecanylamine and octadecanamine working as the capping agents can achieve cyanamides nanorods like Ag2NCN and ZnNCN as well as PbNCN nanoparticles (NPs). The amines used here not only promote the reactions, but also realize their capability in shape control. Then, Niederberger et al [137] reported a full-time catalyst-benzylamine during the synthesis of metal cyanamides. The reaction environment here adopts the molten H2CN2 to disperse metal halides. After the drop of benzylamine, a violent reaction happens in seconds. The obtained nanoparticles smaller than 30 nm mark the fast nucleation process. Nevertheless, the violent and heterogeneous reactions between molten H2CN2 and metal halides bring about obvious agglomeration in Fig. 9g and h, which has bad effects on further applications. Afterwards, solvents are used to dissolve the precursors and relax the reactions by Huang et al [105,118]. The resulted nanoparticles with a size smaller than 10 nm have both good dispersivity and uniformity (Fig. 10 ). Then, quasi-monodisperse CdNCN nanoparticles with various sizes are typically synthesized through this method. As shown in Fig. 10c, the XRD patterns and HRTEM image illustrate that the CdNCN NPs obtained through this way own good crystallinity. It is the first time that metal cyanamides achieve an actual morphology manipulation. It is a great evolution of synthesis strategies for metal cyanamides from bulk fabrication to uniform NPs regulation. The mild conditions not only release the precise equipment, but also improve the repeatability and controllability of the fabrication process. However, up to now, many compounds cannot be obtained or regulated in this way, especially for the transition metal compounds. In order to develop more compounds, it may be a good choice to combine the advances of synthesis for solid-state reactions and manipulation for liquid reactions. 3.2.2 Organometallic intermediate pyrolysis Early transition metal cations as Fe2+, Co2+ and Ni2+ have the non-3d10 electron shells, which remain metastable and like to accept extra electrons to obtain 3d10 state. In addition, the hardness of them are far from the post cations like Zn2+ and Cd2+, leading to the difficulty in further removing the hydrogen atoms from the complex ions [M(NCNH2)4]2+ [96,142]. Thus, the reactions happen in the water cannot reach the complete metal cyanamides for these cations while the intermediates as M(HNCN)2 are always synthesized. Taking FeNCN as an example [55,96], a typical synthesis combines solution reactions and halides flux. The process in the solution is similar to obtain CdNCN and ZnNCN. Excess ammonia is used to coordinate Fe2+ forming [Fe(NH3)6]2+, followed by the drop of H2CN2 resulting in the products of Fe(HNCN)2. Then, it is decomposed and achieves the final FeNCN with a micro-layer morphology (Fig. 11 a) in a halide flux consisting of LiCl/KCl (46:54, mp = 352 °C) at temperatures between 390 and 410 °C under a protective argon atmosphere. In fact, as mentioned in the section 3.1, H2CN2 turns into melamine at about 350 °C and further condenses into triazine above 390 °C. With cations remained in the products, triazine will be decomposed into metal cyanamides after steadyheating. Thus, the halide flux here is just to provide an uniform heating for the Fe(HNCN)2 and the mechanism is the decomposition of melamine obtained from the polymerization of [HCN]− anions. The byproducts from the halide flux verify this theory, which turns out as melamine. CoNCN and NiNCN with a sheet-like shape (Fig. 11b and c) obtained from this method are also based on this theory [97]. All of them show a good crystallinity and overlap compared with the standard crystals (Fig. 11d-f). CuNCN is another compound which can be obtained from indirect synthesis using Cu+. Dronskowski et al [84] reported a strategy which is different from that of MNCN (M = Fe, Co, Ni) to get CuNCN. The Cu+ complexes with [NCN]2− and NH3 from the ammonia to form Cu4(NCN)2NH3 while a further oxidation process results in CuNCN. Apart from these, the strategy to get Si(NCN)2 is also indirect and inspiring [143]. Bis(trimethylsilyl)-carbodiimide (Me3SiNCNSiMe3, BTC) is chosen as the precursor to offer [NCN]2− anions. The reaction process is listed as follows: n SiC l 4 + 2 n BTC = Si NCN 2 n + 4 n M e 3 SiCl Pyridine works as the catalyst to promote this reaction, which is similar as the organic amines in the non-aqueous solution. The obtained Si(NCN)2 is amorphous and the followed annealing at temperatures above 600 °C is needed for crystallization. The non-polar precursor (BTC) plays a significant role during the synthesis to keep the steam away, which would result in the hydrolysis of SiCl4. It is the first time to synthesize cyanamides without H2CN2 to offer [NCN]2− anions in the solution. Up to now, with more and more efforts working for the synthesis of metal cyanamides through soft chemical strategies, morphological manipulation has been realized preliminarily in the size and shape. Although delicate control in the uniformity and variety of shapes is far from the ideal, the existing methods using organic amines to catalyze the reactions with manipulation in morphology shed light on the development of metal cyanamides in academic research and applications. Of course, there are still many transition metal elements like Ti, Mo, W, Nb and so on leaving untouched without new compounds in the family of cyanamides. Thus, more strategies are needed to fill this blank. 3.3 Other methods Many other technologies have been used to realize the synthesis of metal cyanamides besides the main methods mentioned above. As Hyett et al reported [145], ZnNCN film can be obtained through aerosol-assisted chemical vapor deposition. Urea working as the precursor offer [NCN]2− for the reactions while zinc acetate is the cationic raw material. The chemical reaction is listed as follows: Zn O 2 CC H 3 2 + N H 2 2 CO = ZnNCN + H 2 O + 2 C H 3 COOH Urea can be obtained from the hydrolysis of H2CN2 [130]. Thus, a reversible reaction with easy access to get [NCN]2− realizes the synthesis of ZnNCN in the aerosol. Of course, there is another hypothesis that the temperature above 390 °C promotes urea turning into triazine and finally being decomposed into cyanamides. The morphology is shown in Fig. 12 a, which exhibits the same apparent particle size at synthesis temperatures from 425 to 500 °C. According to the Fig. 12b and c, the film having typical peaks of ZnNCN in XRD patterns and FTIR spectra. The peaks at 2021 cm−1, 694 cm−1 and 675 cm−1 are corresponding to asymmetric stretching vibration and deformation vibration of NCN, respectively. In addition, reaction of sodium amide with sodium hydrogen cyanamide at 200 °C in vacuum can obtain Na2CN2 [87]. K2CN2 is got from the potassium metal with liquid ammonia under 580 °C and 90.6 MPa [88]. These methods serve for cyanamides that are difficult to get in normal strategies. In fact, the development of metal cyanamides still remains slow owing to their limited methods. Transition metal cations with multiple valencestates suffer from low “hardness” and are easy to coordinate with H2CN2, which leads to the difficulty in removing the H from H2CN2. Thus, we provide some strategies to work for the synthesis and regulation of transition metal cyanamides. (1) The solid-state synthesis of new transition metal (Ti4+, Mo3+, and W3+) cyanamides with high valence. In most cases, the products obtained from the conventional methods are amorphous complex. According to the case reported by Meyer et al [74], Zr4+ and Hf4+ can exchange with Zn2+ in ZnNCN to form new cyanamides , which have a remarkable similarity to the crystal structure of LiY(NCN)2. The removal of the Li+ interstitial cation from the LiY(NCN)2 structure results in a similar holey structures in Zr(NCN)2 and Hf(NCN)2. It seems to be a smaller size of Li+ that can occupy in the lattice rather than Zn2+, which leads to the ternary cyanamides from Li2CN2 while binary cyanamides from ZnNCN. Hence, we can get new cyanamides from the precursors as MoCl3 or some special precursors with ions groups as (VO)3+. The well-known case is (BiO)2NCN from the reaction between BiOCl and Na2CN2 [58]. Then, triazine from the condensation of melamine is also a good choice to work as precursors to offer [NCN]2−. Calcination of metal precursors from melamine and metal cations is able to make sense. (2) Colloidal synthesis. Si(NCN)2 is the first new family number obtained from liquid [143]. Although it is amorphous from the liquid reaction, Si suffers from low activity and have difficulty in crystallinity so as SiO2 got from solution [146,147]. The reaction system is inspiring because of new nonpolarprecursor-BTC. As a matter of fact, the polarity counts a lot in the manipulation of nanocrystals. Traditional agents applied in the regulation are almost organic amines, acids and phosphine with a long chain like oleylamine. The conflicts among the solvents, surfactants and precursors will result in the nonuniformity and agglomeration of nanocrystals. Huang et al [98] claimed that some amines have the capability in morphology control of Ag2NCN while the polar precursor (H2CN2) leads to the regrets in uniformity and dispersity. Thus, substituting H2CN2 with BTC may realize an ideal manipulation forcyanamides. (3) Cation exchange reactions. Among the strategies in nanocrystal synthesis, ions exchange techniques not only establish the feasibility to rationally design and realize complex nano-architectures using solution routes, but also work in the new compounds’ exploration [118,148,149]. The liquid ions exchange reactions based on HSAB theory like SSM is rather easy to predict and manipulate by choosing ligands and solvents with appropriate affinity to the metal cations. Thus, new metal cyanamides nanocrystals are able to be achieved from the existed cyanamides and remain morphology as well as dispersity. As reported by Zhu et al [150], tertiary phosphines (R3P) can be used to stabilize a variety of transition metal complexes, promoting ions exchange reactions. The mechanism is that R3P donates its P lone pair and thus forms a monodentate terminal metal − PR3 group (σ-bonding) to bind metal ions in the sacrificed nanocrystals (Fig. 13 a). The excess target cations in the solution enter the lattice as soon as the complex getting out, forming new nanocrystals. Based on these consequences, Ag2NCN nanocrystals are the good sacrificial precursors to realize the manipulation of existing metal cyanamides even obtain new compounds. The activity order depending on the group-R of phosphines is listed in Fig. 13b. (4) Template method. Template method is another way to achieve control in morphology for inorganic compounds [151–153]. It means to grow desired compounds in existed templates which are convenient to get and own abundant nanostructures. The key to realize duplicate is localization growth in the templates. Ag2NCN nanoparticles about 20 nm (Fig. 8j and k) have been synthesized by Huang et al [60] in a template of g-C3N4 nanosheet. It is the complexing effect of nitrogen atoms in g-C3N4 planes towards silver ions that restricts the growth of Ag2NCN. Based on this, many other similar templates are able to work for the manipulation of cyanamides, such as h-BN [154], GO [155,156], TMD [157,158] and LDH [159]. The exposed groups with negative charge in the solutions as -N, –COOH, –OH and X2− (X = O, S, Se, Te) play the significant role in the complexing and restricting. Last but not least, the templated synthesis is based on the direct methods in liquid to get cyanamides, which should be attached great importance to develop. 4 Applications Metal cyanamides, known from CaNCN [51,52] as the precursor to produce ammonia or sodium cyanide for industrial applications, have developed many other outlets to appeal attentions from the researchers. In fact, the effects from [NCN] group promote cyanamides for functional applications, among which energy storage and conversion have been widely studied. In order to exhibit the merits of [NCN]2− in electron dynamictransmittingprocessandstaticstoring, the detailed structure–activity relationship and cases will be listed. 4.1 Energy storage Energy storage is always one of the hottest spots in the academics while metal cyanamides call on extensive interests for their extraordinary performance in cycling compared with oxides [55,62,160]. Till now, partial cyanamides have been applied as anodes in lithium ion or sodium ion battery (LIB or SIB). The capacity of these cyanamides are shown in Table 3 . Few reported compounds can serve for supercapacitors or as catalysts in metal-O2 battery [62,65]. As a matter of fact, there are some tips that dominates in a battery for materials as anodes. Firstly, the low redox potentials to get high energy density; secondly, small volume expansion to keep the materials stable; thirdly, high electron- and ion-conductivity to realize excellent rate capability (high power density) [161,162]. It is just the characteristics of [NCN]2− that distinguish them from the corresponding oxides or chalcogenides. According to the report illustrated by Cao et al [62], there is a remarkable advantage for cyanamides contrasted to oxides. [NCN] has a smaller electronegativity than [O], which means the weaker interactions between cations and [NCN] than [O] corresponding to a smaller orbital splitting. Thus, a less energy is required to extract or inject the electrons during a battery cycle and a lower potential for oxidation–reduction reactions is realized. As anodes, the lower potential is corresponding to a wider voltage window and higher energy density for full cell. Firstly, the typical case can be seen in Fig. 14 a that the potential for MnNCN is obvious lower than that for MnO. Secondly, the reported cyanamides exhibit a good reversibility during the cycling even in a high rate (Fig. 14b). After insertion and extraction by Li+ , MnNCN still stays crystalline, which is shown in Fig. 14c. After that, the similar conspicuous comparison between FeNCN and FeO (Fig. 14e) claimed by Stievano et al [55] exhibits its stability as well. Although the theorical capacity for FeNCN (559 mAh g−1) is lower than FeO (744 mAh g−1), a decrease of about 60% of the capacity is observed for FeO/Li after 25 cycles whereas only 20% of the capacity is lost for FeNCN/Li after 50 cycles (Fig. 14d). The performance in SIB (Fig. 14f) also show striking rate stability. There are still few works dedicating in the mechanism of stability for cyanamides, a rational hypothesis can be speculated: A spacious crystal structure keeps the compounds stable from coarsening owing to the smaller expansion under Li+ shuttling back and forth during the cycling. Thirdly, a high rate capability is also declared by cyanamides. As shown in Fig. 14a and b, the discharge capacity of MnNCN is about 725 mAh g−1 at 0.1 A g−1 while 385 mAh g−1 at 5 A g−1, which is superior than most of carbon materials [167,168]. It may contribute from the relatively high electron conductivity arising from the conjugated [NCN] with multi-atom electrons orbital hybridization. The anisotropic [NCN] groups resulted spacious lattice creates Li+ diffusion channels (more than 3 Å in diameter), helping to improve Li+ diffusion rate [55,62]. Then, another strategy for long stability of FeNCN in SIB was reported by Li et al [132]. They adopted ferric ammonium oxalate as the precursor to get FeNCN by annealing. As shown in Fig. 14g, there are few undissociated precursors working as the anchor to connect FeNCN and carbon in the semi-mature FeNCN (S-FeNCN), which shows extraordinary stability than that of the full-mature FeNCN (F-FeNCN) in the cycling of SIB (Fig. 14h). Apart from these, it is interesting that the reported capacity of FeNCN and MnNCN is much more than the theory. The theoretical capacity is 564 mAh g−1 for MnNCN and 559 mAh g−1 for FeNCN through conversion reactions while it turns out as 725 mAh g−1 at 0.1 A g−1 and 600 mAh g−1 at 56 mA g−1 in lithium ion battery (Fig. 14a and d), respectively. The factual capacity of FeNCN in SIB is about 700 mAh g−1 at 100 mA g−1 (Fig. 14h) and is also more than its theoretical capacity. There are still no clear stations to explain this. Cao et al tried Li-ion hybrid capacitors for MnNCN and discovered that a capacity of 276 mAh g−1 was obtained with a window of 0.3–4 V at 0.2 A g−1, which illustrates its advance in energy storage not only in battery but also in supercapacitor. We can draw a preliminary conclusion that the battery behaviors combined with capacitor behaviors happen in the energy storage process, leading to an excess capacity than that from conversion reactions. In addition, there are channels with diameter more than 3 Å [55,169] in the structure of MnNCN and FeNCN that are large enough to accommodate Na+ ions even K+ ions, owing to anisotropic [NCN] groups. Thus, it would be a potential candidate for other alkali metal ions battery as well. Many other cyanamides like CoNCN, NiNCN, ZnNCN, PbNCN, Ag2NCN and CuNCN have been studied in energy storage since Rojo et al [53,160] demonstrated this family is electrochemically active materials. MnNCN and FeNCN representing the family of cyanamides exhibit their striking potential in electrochemical energy-storage systems. Among them, the anisotropic and conjugated [NCN] groups realize remarkable improvement in three tips for anode materials compared with oxides or sulfides. With more and more efforts given in the mechanism research, studying the redox behavior of [NCN]2− anions during the reactions is esteemed by scholars [63]. It would be a reasonable future for cyanamides in energy storage to investigate both the evolution of the structure and the physico-chemical state of the redox centers. 4.2 Energy conversion Energy conversion from dispersedor low-order power to easystorage, transportation and high-order energy is an eternal theme, while catalysis is considered as one of the most effective technics. Metal cyanamides march into the catalytic community owing to their advance in electrons’ separation and transportation [61], which plays a dominant role in the catalytic reactions. (1) Photocatalysis. Ag2NCN as a potential candidate for photocatalysis was firstly reported [61] coming into effect in environment purification. As shown in Fig. 15 a, the Ag2NCN nanoparticles exhibit superior dye degradation rate than that of its microparticles and AgNbO3 under visible light. Then, the proposed mechanism on photo-generated carriers’ separation for Ag2NCN shown in Fig. 15d illustrates that the conjugated structure of [NCN] boosts efficient photocatalytic activity, laying the foundation of cyanamides for further research. After this, many studies about Ag2NCN serving for photocatalysis as hydrogen, oxygen evolution or pollutant degradation are reported [60,98,170,171]. The nanocomposites Ag2NCN/g-C3N4 realize a remarkable improvement of photocatalytic activity than Ag2NCN and g-C3N4 shown in Fig. 15c. It is effective transportation of photo-generated carriers between Ag2NCN and g-C3N4 (Fig. 15e) that plays the key role in the dye degradation process. Apart from these, H2 and O2 evolution reactions through photocatalysis were also reported. However, the position of conduction band (CB) for Ag2NCN is at ~ -0.12 eV while its valance band (VB) is at ~ 2.2 eV. [60] It is more positive than the potential of H2O/H2(−0.42 V) at pH = 7 for CB position that it cannot generate H2 in photocatalysis. The reported H2 evolution results by Liu et al [170] may come from the Z‐scheme photocatalytic systems between TiO2, Ag and Ag2NCN, among which the Ag nanoparticles were obtained from in-situ photocatalysis. On the other hand, the VB position is also more positive than the potential of O2/H2O (0.81 V) for Ag2NCN. Hence, O2 evolution experiments are more suitable for Ag2NCN as is reported by Huang et al [98] and shown in Fig. 15b. Then, the activity for Ag2NCN in photocatalysis shows superiority over a few traditional silver related materials like AgNbO3 and Ag3PO4 [60,61]. Most of the compounds with silver are known from instability with high activity under irradiation of light, while relatively stable and active Ag2NCN emerges as a pioneer to drive scholars working on cyanamides. Afterwards, FeNCN [109], CuNCN [57], ZnNCN [172] and CoNCN [66] are also proved one after another having strong response to sunlight and most have applied in further catalysis (Fig. 16 ). Among them, FeNCN not only exhibits good photocatalytic activity (Fig. 16a) as well as great stability, but also shows striking magnetic performance to realize convenient recovery [109]. CoNCN exhibits superior O2 evolution activity over that of Co3O4 (Fig. 16d and e). To sum up, two points should be emphasized: Firstly, the ratio of covalent bonds between ions in cyanamides is higher than that in oxides arising from the lower electronegativity of [NCN]. Thus, a smaller splitting for cation orbitals results in the smaller bandgap than oxides, which is corresponding to good correlation with solar spectrum. Secondly, the conjugated unsaturated bonds in [NCN]2− not only improve carriers’ separation but also boost their transportation for surface redox reactions. (2) Electrocatalysis. Good transportation also keeps cyanamides active in electrocatalysis. Oxygen evolution reactions (OER) and oxygen reduction reactions (ORR) have been studied with CoNCN, NiNCN, CoχNi1-χNCN and MnNCN (Fig. 17 ) [64–66]. Compared with corresponding oxides, cyanamides have the capability to elevate normalized turnover frequency (TOF/SBET) with two orders of magnitude. Furthermore, cyanamides do not display notable differences from the pristine materials nor any indications for the presence of crystalline metal oxides after oxidation reactions of water [66]. The NiAs structure type of the reported CoNCN opens up interesting alternatives to the long-standing “cube” design paradigm that inspired along line of work to spinels [173]. Another MnNCN has been studied for Li-O2 battery owing to its good electrocatalytic activity for OER and ORR (Fig. 17d). With synergistic effect of MnNCN nanoparticles and N doped carbon, the nanocomposite exhibits the superior electrocatalytic activity with a high specific capacity of 996 mA h g−1 and a lower overpotential of 1.14 V without capacity decay at 100 mA g−1 for 100 cycles (Fig. 17c) [65]. The {Mn-N6} species in MnNCN exhibit strong adsorption to LiO2 and help to transform it into Li2O2, which plays a key role in the Li-O2 battery as the bifunctional electrocatalyst. Hence, the well-designed structure of metal cyanamides catalysts is a novel and promising model system to obtain different theoretical insights into the challenge of existed construction. Nevertheless, still few works concentrate on the research of active sites or catalytic mechanism for cyanamides. The applications in catalysis including photocatalysis and electrocatalysis still remain preliminary in the development. (3) Photoluminescence. Photoluminescence comes from electrons that obtained energy from outside light to go through energy level transition and relaxation. Most of the metal cyanamides possess indirect band gap and show weakness in luminescence. However, the spacious lattice can be a good accommodation for the insertion of luminescent energy levels. The fluorescence performance of the metal cyanamides is mostly based on doping like SrNCN:Eu2+ [69], LiIn(NCN)2:Tb3+ [68], Gd2(NCN)3:Ce3+ or Tb3+ [71] and CaNCN:Mn2+ [67]. LiIn(NCN)2:Tb3+ exhibits low-temperature photoluminescence property owing to the much weaker emission intensity at 200 and 300 K (Fig. 18 b). It demonstrates that strong thermal quenching of the Tb3+. However, it is interesting that the low-temperature quenching of the emission occurs in SrNCN:Eu2+. The emission intensity of it at 10 K (Fig. 18a) corresponds to 85% of the room temperature emission [69]. It is corresponding to a stronger absorption of excitation radiation at higher temperature. Gd2(NCN)3:Ce3+ or Tb3+ and CaNCN:Mn2+ show a strong luminescence performance at room temperature (Fig. 18c and d). The emission light positions range from yellow to red depending on the luminescent activators. Although few cyanamides have intrinsic fluorescence, it may be found in more new compounds in the future. 4.3 Potential applications Except glamorous performances mentioned in supercapacitors, batteries, photoluminescence and catalysis for contaminants removal or O2 evolution, the spacious and stable structure with conjugated anions also comes into effect in many other fields. (1) Cathodes and solid-state electrolyte. The alkali metal-based multielement cyanamides A2M(NCN)3 (A = Li+, Na+; M = Sn4+, Zr4+, Hf4+) have been reported while few come out with applications. Theoretically, Li+ ions accomodated in the channels are able to shuttle out and forth without ruin the structure, owing to its stable structures in Fig. 3. Thus, it may be a great candidate for cathodes in the battery, which suffers from few Li+ ions offering during the cycling for the existed materials [174,175]. The challenge is choosing Mχ+ (χ = 2, 3, 4) that can realize reversible valance change during charge and discharge reactions. By the way, the open holey structure of cyanamides creates high-speed channels not only enabling Li+ ions transportation but also helping work as solid-state electrolyte for all solid-state battery. (2) Catalysis for CO2 reduction. Apart from the applications in energy storage, the conjugated [NCN] groups may be able to apply in CO2 reduction reactions . According to literature reported before, the configurations of adsorbed CO2 on the catalysts surface counts a lot for the products while the activation of CO determines the reactions happen or not [176,177]. In fact, the researches about mechanism of CO2 reduction still remain concentrating on the cations or metals. The catalytic mechanism based on appropriate adsorption and activation is widely accepted, owing to special d or p orbital state of metal cations [178,179]. However, the effect of anions related to the reduction products of CO2 is far from being comprehended. Only some reports illustrate that organic ligands in MOFs or hybrid materials with unsaturated bonds would take part in the reactions to activate CO2 [180,181]. Metal cyanamides not only take conjugated double bonds in structure, but also create spacious channels to accommodate linear CO2. It may challenge the existed metal cations dominated theory and would be an ideal candidate for researchers to study the reduction functions and products of anions. (3) Ion exchange for more complicated heterostructured nanoparticle libraries. The lattice of cyanamides can hold on with stability during the anion exchange [118], which was conventionally considered as nearly impossible without changes in morphology or crystallinity [182,183]. The similarity in cation sublattice and striking lattice endurance of CdNCN and MnNCN makes it possible to achieve real anion exchange reactions in the first time, which remains unchanged in the morphology and crystallinity. It extends the ion exchange reactions as a synthetic toolbox to much broader material libraries and brings cyanamides with oxides, sulfides and many other materials together. Then, a freewheeling manipulation in composition, size, structure and morphology will be realized in chemistry. As enlarged synthetic possibility combining cyanamides with chalcogenides, more applications requiring good physical and electronic stability with superior electronic separation and transportation will bring their talent into full play, such as solar cell, optoelectronic device, carbon dioxide reduction and so on. It sparks future efforts in designing complex nanoarchitecture with potentials in various functional applications. 5 Summary and perspectives In this review, we summarized the progress of structures, physiochemical properties, morphology control methods and applications for metal cyanamides in recent years. Till now, nearly all of the reported metal cyanamides exhibit semi-conductivity. The related lower ligand-field splitting created by unique anions [NCN]2− than corresponding oxides help to get their magnetism property. The instability under acid or high temperature help them to realize functional framework design. Although morphology regulation is still in their infancy, nanoparticles, nanorods and aggregated nanosheets have been obtained. The conjugated electronic structures and holey frameworks enable their striking performance in batteries, supercapacitors, photocatalysis, electrocatalysis and doping for luminescence. However, the application potential of cyanamides for industry is still far from ideal compared with oxides or sulfides on the market. Most researches on cyanamides in recent years concentrate on the synthesis of new compounds and analysis of structures. The nonequivalent development between synthesis and applications prevents cyanamides from spreading. Applications like catalysis suffer from few choices of compounds and low activity of bulk materials. The specific functions of [NCN] in the applications are still left to moulder. It definitely restricts their improvement in performance. Hence, we give some perspectives for cyanamides including new compounds synthesis and morphological manipulation strategies. In a few words, the potential strategies for synthesis and manipulation of cyanamides can be summarized into five points: (1) ZnNCN can work as a sacrificial compound to get transition metal cyanamides with higher valence than + 2 through SSM reactions. (2) Melamine is another choice to provide [NCN] groups and get cyanamides through calcination. (3) The [NCN] group derivatives like BTC are new precursors enabling morphology control. (4) Tertiary phosphines should be a good choice to help achieve manipulation through cation exchange reactions. (5) The templated fabrication for cyanamides is based on existed solution methods. The advances in the synthesis of metal cyanamides pave the way for application research. The unique structure created by [NCN]2− anions not only can work in the traditional applications like anodes in batteries or catalysis for H2O dissociation and contaminants degradation, but also make sense in many other fields such as cathodes, solid-state electrolyte, catalysis for CO2 reduction and even for complex functionalized framework design as the colloidal synthons. From our point of view, the study of metal cyanamides, their properties and applications are exciting. It may introduce a new and potential family of multifunctional materials for fundamental research and industrial applications. Bingquan Jia is currently a Ph.D. student in Shanghai Institute of Ceramics, Chinese Academy of Sciences under the supervision of Prof. Fuqiang Huang. He obtained his B.S. degree in Nanjing University of Science and Technology in 2016. His research focuses on controllable synthesis of nano metal cyanamides and applications in energy conversion and storage. Dr. Du Sun received his bachelor’s degree in Applied Chemistry at the Beihang University in 2008. He got a Ph.D. degree in Chemistry from the Pennsylvania State University in 2016, where he conducted research on the colloidal synthesis of complex nanostructures based on layered transition metal dichalcogenides and other inorganic compounds. He then joined the department of Materials Science and Engineering in Johns Hopkins University for his postdoctoral research on the active material design for the electrocatalysis of carbon dioxide and oxygen reduction. Starting from 2018, he works as associate researcher in the Shanghai Institute of Ceramics, Chinese Academy of Sciences and focuses on the rational design and synthesis of active materials for energy conversion and storage. Wei Zhao obtained his B.E. degree in Material Physics and Chemistry at Wuhan University in China in 2009. He then completed his Ph.D. under the supervision of Prof. Fuqiang Huang at Shanghai Institute of Ceramics, Chinese Academy of Sciences (SICCAS), in 2014. From 2014 to 2016, he worked as a Research Fellow in Prof. Hua Zhang’s group at the School of Materials Science and Engineering in Nanyang Technological University in Singapore. He currently holds a position at SICCAS, working on low dimensional nanomaterials for energy conversion and storage. Prof. Fuqiang Huang received his B.E. degree from Nanjing University of Science and Technology in 1990, a MS degree from Jilin University in 1993, and a Ph.D. from Beijing Normal University in 1996. From 1996 to 2003, he worked in the United States as a research staff member in the Department of chemistry of University of Michigan, Northwestern University, OSI Company of Siemens Group and University of Pennsylvania. From 2004, he became a Professor of Shanghai Institute of Ceramics, Chinese Academy of Sciences. His current research interests focus on the rational design of functional materials for energy applications.

coredata.dc:description: Metal cyanamides are an emerging class of functional materials with potential applications in sustainable energy conversion and storage technologies such as catalysis, supercapacitors, photoluminescence and next-gen batteries. The [NCN]2− as the anion, which is isolobal with [O]2− endows metal cyanamides with similar physicochemical properties as oxides and chalcogenides. Whereas the unique quasi-linear structure and electronic resonance between [NCN]2− and [N–CN]2− of [NCN] entity bring out superior properties beyond oxides and chalcogenides. In this review, we present research status, challenges, and the recent striking progress on the metal cyanamides in the synthesis and applications. Specifically, the characteristic structures, physicochemical properties, synthetic methods with corresponding merits/demerits and latest applications in energy conversion and storage of cyanamides are summarized. The detailed outlooks for the new compounds design, morphology manipulation and potential applications are also exhibited.
